topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Melissa Perri and Denise Tilles and frames the episode around defining product operations, how it differs from adjacent roles, and how to build the function as companies scale.

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
topics.summary: Ad read for Jira Product Discovery, positioning it as a tool to centralize ideas, prioritize, and share roadmaps while reducing spreadsheet-driven alignment work.

topics.title: How common product ops is now
topics.summary: They discuss the rapid rise of product ops across scaling tech companies, including early origins in large firms and how adoption has accelerated over the last ~5 years.

topics.title: Why product ops exists and when you need it
topics.summary: They explain the core benefit: freeing PMs to focus on strategic, outcome-driven work by removing operational burdens like data wrangling and coordination, and share signals that a company is ready.

topics.title: Defining product ops: the three pillars
topics.summary: Denise outlines product ops as three pillars—business/data insights, customer/market insights, and process/practices—while Melissa explains which pillars tend to matter most by company stage.

topics.title: Customer and market insights vs user research
topics.summary: They describe how product ops supports qualitative insight flow by building research repositories, participant panels, and feedback loops from sales/support—without replacing user researchers or PM discovery work.

topics.title: How product ops changes the PM role
topics.summary: They argue product ops is a major evolution in product management, reducing context switching and operational overhead for both PMs and product leaders so they can focus on strategy and outcomes.

topics.title: What PMs should not delegate to product ops
topics.summary: Melissa clarifies boundaries: product ops should not take decision rights, prioritize features, manage engineers, or handle stakeholder trade-offs; PMs remain accountable for outcomes and product decisions.

topics.title: Go-to-market coordination and breaking silos
topics.summary: They discuss how product ops can improve go-to-market execution by standardizing templates, creating cadences, and coordinating across sales/marketing/product—while PMs still own the substance of GTM inputs.

topics.title: Product ops vs project and program management
topics.summary: They distinguish product ops as enabling better decision-making through the three pillars, while program/project management focuses more on initiative coordination and time-boxed delivery (with some role overlap in practice).

topics.title: Business and data insights: what product ops does
topics.summary: They explain how product ops connects BI/data science/finance to product needs, builds product-health dashboards (e.g., by segment/product line), and equips leaders with repeatable, decision-ready insights.

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
topics.summary: Second ad read for Jira Product Discovery, emphasizing prioritization, roadmapping, and cross-functional collaboration built on Jira.

topics.title: Ops as leverage: automation, sizing, and hiring
topics.summary: They discuss product ops as a lean, leverage-focused function that should automate and standardize repeatable work; they cover rough sizing heuristics, starting with one hire, and matching hires to pillar-specific expertise.
